## PHYSICS

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 587, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 101, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 920, 105]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows two identical cylindrical conductors P and Q, each of length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 117, 840, 315]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 331, 532, 347]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 362, 920, 394]]<|/det|>
<pre>The conductors are placed parallel to each other. The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of P to point X is \(p\). The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of Q to point X is \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 408, 918, 456]]<|/det|>
<pre>The two conductors are electrically connected in parallel. This parallel combination is connected in series to a power supply and a resistor. The potential difference \(V\) between the ends of P is the same as the potential difference between the ends of Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 471, 715, 487]]<|/det|>
<pre>The magnetic flux density at X due to the currents in the conductors is \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 501, 580, 517]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is suggested that \(B\) is related to \(p\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[427, 522, 576, 554]]<|/det|>
\[
B=\frac{Y A V}{L p}+\frac{Y Z A V}{L q}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 564, 363, 580]]<|/det|>
<pre>where Y and Z are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 594, 693, 610]]<|/det|>
<pre>Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(B\) and \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 625, 625, 641]]<|/det|>
<pre>Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 655, 699, 671]]<|/det|>
<pre>Explain how the results could be used to determine values for Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 685, 383, 701]]<|/det|>
<pre>In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 716, 393, 732]]<|/det|>
<pre>• the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 747, 410, 763]]<|/det|>
<pre>• the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 778, 347, 794]]<|/det|>
<pre>• the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 809, 350, 825]]<|/det|>
<pre>• the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 840, 446, 856]]<|/det|>
<pre>• any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 72, 114, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 72, 582, 88]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the cooling of a liquid in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 103, 707, 120]]<|/det|>
The temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the laboratory is measured using a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 134, 643, 150]]<|/det|>
Hot water is added to an insulated beaker, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[239, 161, 760, 406]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 422, 532, 438]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 453, 918, 485]]<|/det|>
The thermometer measures the temperature of the water. At time \(t\) the temperature of the water is \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 500, 454, 516]]<|/det|>
A series of readings of \(t\) and \(\theta\) are taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 530, 563, 546]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\theta\) and \(t\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 558, 593, 581]]<|/det|>
\[
\theta=\theta_{\mathrm{R}}+(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}) \mathrm{e}^{-(\frac{t}{k})}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 596, 578, 612]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta_{0}\) is the temperature at \(t=0\) and \(K\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 627, 707, 643]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label> A graph is plotted of \(\ln \left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right)\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(t\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 611, 673]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 842, 885, 858]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 873, 885, 889]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 893, 920, 909]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 942, 315, 965]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 944, 550, 955]]<|/det|>
9702/52/F/M/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[825, 944, 905, 955]]<|/det|>
[Turn over

\(t/\min\)\(\theta/^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)\((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})/^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)\(\ln\left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})/^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\right)\)

Include error bars for \(\ln\left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})/^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 535, 866, 551]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 565, 184, 581]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 565, 918, 597]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 593, 866, 609]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[147, 613, 184, 629]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 613, 918, 645]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[499, 844, 520, 860]]<|/det|> gradient = ............................................................
